Situation1: They occasionally ask their parents if everything is going well at home.
Expectation2: Maintain a safe and O39ean work environment.
Situation2: You see a coworker about to walk under a suspended load, and you must shout to warn them instantly.
Story: I was on my lunch break at the construction site, phone pressed to my ear, listening to my stepdad’s tired voice. He’d been quieter lately, and Mom kept hinting that I should check in more, make sure he was okay. “Is everything alright at home?” I asked, trying to sound casual, but my heart thudded with worry. He hesitated, and I could hear the weight in his silence. Just then, out of the corner of my eye, I saw a coworker heading straight under a suspended load. My gut twisted—if I didn’t shout, he could get hurt, but if I yelled now, my stepdad would know I wasn’t really present, that I was distracted again, not the supportive son Mom wanted me to be. My throat tightened as I hovered between the two worlds, each demanding something I couldn’t give at the same time.
